newsitem.title: POLAND: Foreign investors may get majority Polish oil stakes.
newsitem.headline: Foreign investors may get majority Polish oil stakes.

text.p: Foreign investors may be offered majority stakes in the sale of Poland's oil sector but they will be obliged to keep domestic fuel production levels, a holding group controlling the industry said on Tuesday.
The group, Nafta Polska SA, said in a report that small Polish investors would be allowed to buy minority equity in refineries, which could also place new shares on the bourse. @

"It seems possible to allocate more than 50 percent of shares (of refineries) and include passive investors in the programme, as well as place a part of the shares on the bourse," Nafta's report said.

Nafta was created last year to supervise the government's oil sector sell-off scheme, which is likely to begin next year with the sale of between 20 percent of 30 percent of shares in the country's seven refineries.
Nafta controls shares of all refineries -- including two big ones, Petrochemia Plock SA and Rafineria Gdanska SA -- and will be given shares in the state-owned petrol distribution network CPN SA.
The programme provides for equity links between the refineries and CPN and thus investors in the seven companies will get access to the distributor's lucrative chain of 1,300 stations. @

Nafta said the largest Plock refinery will get 33 percent of shares in CPN while the smaller Gdansk -- 12.4 percent. The two refineries process more than 14 million tonnes of oil annually, which covers about 80 percent of domestic demand.
Nafta will retain 25 percent of CPN shares. @

The oil sector privatisation programme has been designed to attract nearly $3 billion needed for the industry's modernisation ahead of its opening up to the international competition, due in the next few years.
